user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskExit:
```c
void OS_TaskExit()
{
    osal_id_t         task_id;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    task_id = OS_TaskGetId_Impl();
    if (OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_TaskDetach_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(OS_SUCCESS, &token);
    }

    /* call the implementation */
    OS_TaskExit_Impl();

    /* Impl function never returns */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(OS_SUCCESS, &token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: If the function OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete has the prototype OS_Status_t OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(OS_Status_t status, OS_object_token_t *token) (i.e. pointer to non-const) but the function does not modify the object referred to by token, then the pointer parameter should be const-qualified (const OS_object_token_t *). In that case the call OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(OS_SUCCESS, &token); indicates a violation of Rule 8.13 because a pointer is not pointing to a const-qualified type when it could be.
